caseTitle: EMMANUEL ROCKSON v ILIOS SHIPPING COMPANY S.A. AND WILTEX
summary: In Emmanuel Rockson v Ilios Shipping Company S.A. and Wiltex Ltd., the plaintiff, a mariner injured aboard the M/V Dynamic while docked in Beirut, sought compensation under a collective insurance policy. The case reached the Ghanaian Supreme Court on appeal after the Court of Appeal reversed a High Court ruling that had dismissed a preliminary strike-out application. The Supreme Court found that the plaintiff's writ of summons was a nullity because it failed to disclose a cause of action, contrary to the mandatory requirements of Order 2 Rule 1 of the High Court (Civil Procedure) Rules 1954. Relying on the precedent in Republic v High Court, Tema; Ex parte Owners of MV Esco Spirit [2003-2004] SCGLR 689, the Court held that a writ lacking a substantive claim is invalid and cannot support any legal proceedings. Despite the plaintiff's assertion of a workmen's compensation claim, the Court dismissed the appeal due to the fatal procedural defect, without addressing jurisdictional or limitation issues.
verdict: The appeal was dismissed due to the nullity of the writ of summons for failure to disclose a cause of action.
citations: Republic v High Court, Tema; Ex parte Owners of MV Esco Spirit (Darya Shipping SA Interested Party) [2003-2004] SCGLR 689
Okofoh Estates v Modern Signs Ltd. [1996-97] SCGLR 224
rationaleHighlights: The writ of summons was a nullity because it failed to disclose a cause of action as required by Order 2 Rule 1 of the High Court (Civil Procedure) Rules 1954.
The Supreme Court relied on Republic v High Court, Tema; Ex parte Owners of MV Esco Spirit [2003-2004] SCGLR 689, which established that a writ not endorsed with a substantive claim is a nullity.
The plaintiff's supplementary submissions failed to address the fundamental defect in the writ.
Even pending motions to amend the writ do not cure the existing nullity.
The appeal was dismissed without considering other grounds due to the fatal flaw in the writ.
